speechtext: Report of the Secretary of State for Canada for the year ending June 30, 1900.-Right Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier.

I have the honour to inform the House that I have received from the Hon. Mr. Justice Hodgson and the Hon. Mr. Justice Fitzgerald, two of the judges selected for the trial of election petitions, jiursuant to the Dominion Controverted Elections Act, a certificate relating to the electoral district of East Queen's, in the province of Prince Edward Island, by which the said election is declared to be void.
I have further to inform the House that the trial judges having reported
(c) That there is reason to believe that corrupt practices, namely, treating, extensively prevailed at the election to which the petitions relate.
(<f) We are of opinion that the inquiry into the circumstances of the said election has been rendered incomplete by the action of the parties to the said petitions, and that further inquiry as to the extent such corrupt practices prevailed is desirable.
I have, in conformity with section 48, chap. 9 of the Revised Statutes of Canada, withheld the issue of my warrant for a new election pending any action to be taken by the House in the matter.

speakername: The PRIME MINISTER (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier) moved :

speechtext: Motion agreed to.
The MINISTER OF FINANCE (Hon. AV. S. Fielding) moved that the House resolve itself into Committee of Supply.

['My instructions were that all committees should be summoned for Thursday. If that has not been done in the case of the Public Accounts Committee it must have been a mistake. X will see to it that the committee is summoned for the following day.']

Mr. Speaker, before we enter into the consideration of that motion, I desire to bring an amendment before the attention of the House, dealing with the question of the government ownership of railways in this country. I have framed an amendment on the narrowest lines possible in order to elicit the fullest discussion, and in order to present the matter before the House and the public in a wide and clear manner. When, the other day, I brought this question to the attention of the House by moving the adjournment of the House, I was criticised because it was said that I was out of order, and that I was springing the question upon the House and the country. I am here to justify what I did then, because what I did then secured for me a very prompt expression of opinion from one end of the country to the other, and if I am moving to-day in a more regular way, it is because, to-day, I have at my disposal an expression of opinion that comes from one end of Canada to the other, and which proves the gravity and indicates the importance of this question, and which justifies me in bringing it up now on a motion to go into Supply. In the short week which has elapsed since I first made the motion, I have had expressions of opinion from all over the country ; from the press and from the public men of Canada endorsing my course ; and, in the discussion to-day these expressions of opinion will throw a great deal of light upon the subject. What is the question to which I direct the attention of the House and of the country ? It is the gravity of the fact that the great railroads of Canada are liable at any moment to pass into the control of that great monopolistic syndicate which has recently acquired control of the great railways of the United States. The future of Canada is involved in that question, and therefore if I take up a little time of the House in trying to make my position good, I trust hon. gentlemen will pardon me. Let me first give a sketch of these men in the United States who control the railways, and I shall do so by way of illustration. At the head of that combination is Mr. J. Pierpont Morgan, of New York, who to-day is the collossus of banking in the world. There is not a proposition that he will not undertake; he frequently puts schemes through which involve
from fifty million dollars to a thousand million dollars. He commands almost the entire banking support of the United States, and he has associated with him men of great experience and capacity ; men like the head of the Vanderbilt family, owning thousands of miles of railroads in the United States; men like Mr. George Gould, who controls thousands of miles of railway, as well as the telegraph system of the United States largely ; men like Mr. Rockefeller, the head of the Standard Oil Company, who also controls thousands of miles of railway ; men like Mr. Harriman, also a great railway owner, and these men, along with others, form to-day, the most powerful combination that ever existed in the United States. Within the past few weeks they have consolidated the Vanderbilt lines, the Gould lines, all the Pacific lines, including the Northern Pacific, the Union Pacific, the Great Northern, and the Southern Pacific. These men not only control the railroads of the United States, but they control also other great corporations. AVithin a week they have secured control of the iron and steel production of the United States, capitalized at $950,000,000. They control the oil production of the United States, through the Standard Oil Company; they control the copper production of the United States ; they control all the coal fields in the Eastern States and the Southern States, and the coal fields of Ohio, and they are preparing to control the ship-building of the United States. There is not a single proposition of the first magnitude that these same men do not seek to control.
What is still more significant to the people of this country to-day is the fact that they also control the service of Mr. C. M. Hays, who was the manager of the Grand Trunk Railway, and who is to-day to be the manager of the consolidated system-a man whom all the world admits is the greatest administrator of railway in America and who, having been in the service of the Grand Trunk, and knowing the transportation problems of Canada, as no other man in America knows them, is in a position by reason of his connection with this great syndicate and his knowledge of our railway, to lay out a scheme whereby in the twinkling of an eye the two great Canadian railways could pass into the hands of this syndicate. And even if they do not pass into the hands of this syndicate, they could be greatly injured by him.
They also control steamship and river lines of steamers, on the Pacific, on the Atlantic and on many of the inland waters of the United States.
Now, Sir, if they can control the railways of the United States, I am here to-day to argue that they can control the railways of Canada in a very easy manner, and since I raised this question last week, we have had the opinion of Mr. Shaughnessy, the head of the Canadian Pacific Railway, to show how

easy it would be for this powerful United States syndicate to control our Canadian railroads. In an authentic interview given out by Mr. Shaughnessy, he makes this statement :

Shaughnessy, president of the Canadian Pacific Railway, was asked by a Herald representative to-day as to what he thought of the possibility of the Canadian Pacific Railway being acquired by a powerful syndicate of United States capitalists, as was stated in the course of the debate on government ownership of railways in the House of Commons yesterday afternoon.
' Oh, it is quite possible,' continued Mr. Shaughnessy; ' there is nothing whatever to prevent American capitalists, if they have got the money, from buying the stock of the Canadian Pacific Railway, which is for sale in London and Montreal, and on Berlin and other continental bourses. Having acquired the stock, there is nothing to prevent these gentlemen from controlling the policy of the company, and exercising their control for the advancement of United States interests.'
Now, not only can these men control these railways at a comparatively small cost-as Mr. Shaughnessy has said, of $30,000,000- but they can control these railways by the simple act of leasing them, for which they will only have to pay a very small consideration. We therefore see that these men can any day acquire control of both of our great Canadian roads for a mere nominal sum. And not only that they could ruin the Canadian manufacturer and the Canadian citizen toy the local rates which they could impose on our local traffic and by the preferences which they could give to American products and manufactures coming into this country. They could if they liked, in this strong position hold us in the hollow of their hand. We would all be their serfs and their servitors.
And if they once started to gobble up our railways, they could gobble up our great lines of production, just as they have got control of the iron and steel and copper and petroleum production in the United States.
We have been discussing the status of these roads from another point of view, and recently it has been pointed out that their management at the present day is a menace to our country. It has been charged against them, the Grand Trunk Railway particularly, that they were discriminating against Canadian ports, and rendering almost useless the great sums of money we have spent on our canal system, on our harbour improvements, and on the deepening of the St. Lawrence route. If these railroads can do that to-day, how much more injurious would it be to this country were they to pass into the hands of a United States syndicate. Today the fight is between the American shipping ports as against the St. Lawrence route, and do you think that if these men who have all their interests bound up in the ports of New York, Boston, Baltimore and Philadelphia, could get control of the Canadian rail-Mr. MACLEAN.
ways, that they would not use that power to the detriment of Canada. This question is therefore, to us, one of supreme national importance, and that is why I have thus early availed of the opportunity to bring it before the parliament of Canada. Why, this syndicate could render nugatory the effects of all the money we have spent in building up our canals and in trying to create great shipping ports in Montreal, in Quebec, in St. John, and in Halifax. These men could do all that by spending fifty million dollars in buying the control of our railways, or easier still for them, by leasing the roads. And, Sir, they would have no hesitation in doing it.
My argument in favour of government control of railways is, in the first place, because I wish to stop the unpatriotic management of these roads towards Canada, and in the second place, I wish to try and prevent our railways falling into the hands of United States monopolists. I have two arguments in my favour. First, that these roads on which Canada has spent so much money in the way of subsidies are to-day inimical to the interests of Canada ; and second, that they are liable to fall into the hands of these men in the United States. These, I submit, Sir, are two good reasons in favour of my contention. In order that X may bring the mind of the House clearly to this matter, I propose to read some expressions of public opinion which have been given within the past week on this question. I shall first quote the Hamilton Herald, which says :	.
Few speeches delivered in the Dominion are more worthy of serious attention than the one which was made yesterday hy the member for East York (Mr. Maclean). It was a very bold and radical speech, and a very important one. Mr. Maclean advocated the acquirement by the government of the whole interest in the Canadian Pacific Railway and the Grand Trunk Railway as a means of averting the great danger. The proposition is made not so much as a matter of general national policy as because the nationalization of the railways is the only adequate means of defence against the national danger arising out of new and unexpected conditions. Even more significant and important than Mr. Maclean's advocacy of this policy is Mr. Charlton's tacit endorsation of it. The member for East York has for some years been an advocate of national railways; but Mr. Charlton has never given any hint of favouring such a radical innovation. The member for North Norfolk is a prudent, cautious politician, inclining to conservatism; and the fact that he favours the serious consideration of Mr. Maclean's proposal will go far to save that proposal from ridicule as one of Billy Maclean's fads.
La Patrie on the same day says :
The situation is far from being a desperate one; it is neither dark nor compromising as depicted by fantastic rumours. But the present agitation will open the eyes of those who had refused to see, and will cause those with serious thoughts to give careful attention and' efficacious protection to our great natural interests.

Here is an extract from another paper which I think will appeal to the House, namely, the Montreal Witness \
There are few persons who have been observing how the interests that are developing Canada have been falling into few hands, and many of these foreign, who have not wondered what might be the effect of it all on self-government and on Canadian nationality. Whether or not there be anything in the fear expressed by Mr. Maclean of the Canadian Pacific Railway falling into the tentacles of the all-absorbing railway octopus now developing in the United States, the bare mention of such a possibility must awaken serious reflections in the minds of all who remember the nature and extent of the sacrifices made by the country to secure the construction of that great transcontinental railway. If such an extraordinary anti-climax to an undertaking, originally designed to knit the scattered provinces together and make this country independent of the United States in matters of transportation, could have entered the minds of the statesmen who projected the railway, we may be sure they would have provided securely against it in the charter and Act of incorporation. The magnitude of the new power which has come into existence on this continent, however, with its unconcealed intention of controlling transportation between the two oceans, gives colour to the apprehensions expressed in parliament, extravagant though they may appear. The Canadian Pacific Railway is of the nature of an Impreial highway, as it is certainly an alternative route between Britain and the east. Such being the fact, its control by foreign and possibly hostile capitalists is a contingency not to be contemplated. Like the Suez canal, as Mr. Maclean says, it is an Imperial necessity. It has long been boasted as Canada's contribution to the empire's defences. It must remain a national enterprise. Mr. Maclean's proposal that this should be accomplished as Lord Beaconsfield secured the key of the east, is one which, should it be the right one, will not perhaps be facilitated by the public proposal of it. In taking the readiest way to answer the Sphinx's riddle and to unlock the Asian mystery, that Oriental magician did not propose at the same time to solve the great economic problem of the west, nor do we know that the way proposed is the right one. We only know that the question is a live one, full of electricity.
I am not going to read all the press opinions which I have, but I wish to read some extracts from an article in the Toronto Globe of only Friday last. The Globe says :
Mr. Shaughnessy says that there is nothing whatever to prevent American capitalists from buying the stock of the Canadian Pacific Railway, which is for sale in London, Montreal, and on the Berlin and other European exchanges. Having acquired the stock, there is nothing to prevent them from controlling the policy of the company and exercising their control for the advancement of United States interests. He might have added that there was nothing to prevent them exercising their power to the positive detriment of Canadian interests without overstating the case. The danger is even more immediate, for there is nothing to prevent the present owners of the road, whether they be Canadians, Americans or Germans, from operating the road in such a way as to favour foreign at the expense of domestic enterprises. In fact,
the present management have been convicted of such lines of policy on many occasions, not adopted for the purpose of favouring Americans or hurting Canadians, but that they might augment net receipts regardless of consequences. Such restrictions as have been placed on the transfer of stock in the Canadian Pacific Railway agreement seem rather for the protection of the company than to preserve the national character of the road. But even if there was a specific provision against the sale of stock to foreigners, it would be of no avail, for the exactions of a Canadian company would be quite as onerous as any pressure that could be applied by foreigners. The danger lies in the absence of any defence, against discrimination injurious to Canada. This defect has been mentioned by Mr. Shaughnessy, and it should be remedied, as far as possible, by the creation^ of machinery for controlling services and regulating rates.
Here is wliat the Globe says on government ownership :
With regard to the agitation for government purchase and operation, Mr. Shaughnessy expressed the view that it would be a far better policy to buy out roads like the Canadian Pacific and Grand Trunk than to subsidize and construct useless lines. He says emphatically that we have had too much wasting of public money in the past for the building of railways which are not only in themselves useless but are positively injurious, inasmuch as they cripple the lines already built. This, he says, is very pernicious, and it would be far preferable that the government should take over the existing lines than that they should build new ones to compete with them. All who have studied the history of competitive railway building in Canada and the United States will see the wisdom of this position. In every case where two roads have been constructed to do the xvork of one the result has been the maintenance of rates by agreement and the imposition of a double burden on the community. The people have been required to maintain two equipments instead of one, and the greater cost of management has militated against any reduction of rates. If anything has been established and settled by the experience of the past it is that railway competition is not often an effective means of regulating railway charges. Only an unreasoning and destructive obduracy that no business man would be likely to indulge in would justify the government in paralleling existing railways. We may get an exaggerated idea of the waste of parallel roads through the contemplation of railway maps. Unnecessary duplication of roads by the government would be a great waste of capital, and while it would not cost the government any more than the purchase of existing roads, it would mean the destruction of a great amount of capital already invested in the railways.
That is the opinion of the Toronto Globe of Friday last. Here is an extract from a St. John paper, the Gazette-this is directly the opposite of the wind-tip of the Globe article :
Perhaps the best way to meet the combination is by the construction of a government line of railway from Montreal to Parry Sound and another from Montreal to the Detroit river. This would prevent railroad combination from charging excessive rates of freight in the most populous sections of Canada and would furnish

means of transportation independent of company railroads to the great west. The Gazette is strongly in favour of fast transcontinental railroad owned and operated by the government of Canada. It has been shown time and again that less than one-half of the proceeds of the sale of stocks and bonds of railroads constructed in Canada has gone into the road-bed or equipment of these lines. .	. _.	. The time is
not far distant when Canadians will be compelled to grapple with the question of transportation rates, because if we only paid rates proportionate to the cost of moving the freight and allowing a fair interest on the actual cost of the roadbed and equipment, freight rates in Canada would be cut in two. The question is one which requires great consideration and careful legislation. It is a question which the Minister of Railways has already given great consideration, and he will probably be able at an early date to present legislation which will prevent any further inroad on public rights by railroad corporations or combinations.
Here is a brief extract from the London Advertiser, a prominent Liberal paper :
The question thus raised is a very large one, but not less large and formidable would be the proper handling if any remedy could be proposed. But these are the sort of questions which, before the twentieth century is very old, may compel men to sit up and think.
The London News says :
Mr. Maclean has stated that the government, that is the people of Canada, could secure control of the Canadian Pacific by the expenditure of $50,000,000. That looks like a large sum, and it is a large sum, but the question, to the Neios' mind, is simply whether that money shall be spent now, and the people of Canada be given a chance to transport their goods and do business on a fair basis, or whether we shall wait until the Canadian Paciflc Railway, the Grand Trunk Railway and the other big Canadian roads pass under the control of the United States railroad trust, and then have to be bought out at an enhanced figure.
There are many problems connected with government ownership of railways, and business methods would have to be strictly adhered to in the event of the government securing control of the Canadian Paciflc Railway, but these problems will be no easier of solution in the future than now, and meanwhile the plundering of the country by exorbitant rates will have been going steadily on.
The situation has apparently got to be faced. Why not do as Mr. Maclean suggests and face it now?
The next authority I want to quote is the hon. the Minister of Public Works (Hon. Mr. Tarte), who addressed a letter the other day to the Montreal Board of Trade, in which he made the following remarks :
The American railways are equipping themselves in a most energetic and modern manner in order that they may he able to carry cheaper and cheaper every day the western trade to the ports of the United States. I greatly fear that unless we make an earnest effort on behalf of Canada, we will lose much of the benefits and advantages of the improvements that we have made to the St. Lawrence route.
In my humble opinion, we must not lose one moment. The St. Lawrence route must be overhauled, made deeper and wider, and as safe as possible from one end to the other, In order

to provide cheap and quick transportation from the west to the European markets.
The more I study the map of Canada the more I feel convinced that the ports on the Georgian Bay are destined to become splendid reservoirs and recipients of trade. All that trade can be secured to the St. Lawrence route if we make the necessary effort.
Tlie consequence, I believe, of what the hon. minister here says cannot be anything else than government ownership.
Let me read just two more newspaper extracts. The Winnipeg Free Press says :
It behooves the people of Canada to take some notice of symptoms that have lately developed among railway companies controlling the chief railways in Canada, of an effort to coerce this country by threatening to injure Canadian ports by transferring their trade and terminals to United States ports. .	.	. This practically amounts to an attempt to establish a system of terrorism and to frighten the Canadian people from taking steps which they consider proper. It is, therefore, a reasonable thing that the public should look to the government to exercise all possible control over these roads, and by legislation, if possible, prevent them from injuring what they were subsidized to build up and improve.
Tbe St. Thomas Times says :
If the government has no other means of stopping this anti-Canadian policy on the part of the Canadian railways, it should have no hesitation in putting Mr. McNaught's suggestion into practice.
That suggestion is that a preferential tariff should only be allowed on goods that come in by Canadian ports.
The St. John Telegraph of February 15, says :
But the interests of the country, and particularly of these maritime provinces, demand some such radical cure for the present trouble.
The writer in the above quotation refers to Mr. McNaught's remedy for the discrimination by Canadian railways against Canadian ports.
The St. John Telegraph of February 14, says :
The latter idea [the extension of the Intercolonial to the Georgian Bay] was outlined by the Minister of Railways in his speeches in St. John prior to the general elections. Such a movement will check for ever any possibility of American railway magnates monopolizing the constantly increasing transportation of Canadian products to the eastern seaboard.
I can hardly agree in the opinion that the extension of the Intercolonial Railway by the government will settle the question. That would only aggravate the situation, although I have supported in the past and may, under certain circumstances to-day, defend that proposition.
I have one more letter to read, out of many similar ones which I have received : Dear Sir,-I am much pleased to read of the stand you have taken with reference to the government ownership of railways. The stand you have taken is well chosen, and it is difficult to imagine any other way to escape from the railways of Canada being absorbed by the gigantic

combine that evidently has for one of its objects to get hold of and control our railways. Could they accomplish their design, then the independence of the Canadian people will exist in name only. For it is a self-evident fact that if any corporation can control the means of transportation in Canada, they can then dictate their terms in other directions. So far as I can learn, the system of government ownership in some European countries seems to give general satisfaction to the travelling and commercial public. One of the advantages is, that it for ever shuts out all gambling in stocks, and special rates to favoured localities or individuals. As I am a stranger to you, I will refer you to our member, A. E. Vrooman, or Hon. George McHugh; also will add that I am a lifelong Reformer. But your step is in the right direction, and of my own knowledge, know that a large percentage of the people were looking in the direction of government ownership before this movement was inaugurated. So you can easily see how much more interest will be taken in this matter now. You are at liberty, if-you see fit, to use this letter for any purpose that will suit your convenience.
What is the name ?

Mr. Minthorne, of Oak-wood.
I think, Sir, I have proved to the House that a seriotis problem is before us. 1 think I have proved, by quoting the leading newspapers of the country and by a reference to the language used by two members of the government, that we have to grapple with a very serious problem; and having made that point, I think it is incumbent on me to make some practical suggestion. That practical suggestion is that there can be no radical cure of these evils except government ownership. You will says perhaps that government ownership involves a very large financial proposition. I said the other day that it would take $50,000,000 to acquire the Canadian Pacific Railway. I spoke wide of the mark intentionally, and have since found out that less than $30,000,000 invested on the stock exchanges to-day would secure control of the Canadian Pacific Railway. and also that for less than $20,000,000 you can secure control of the shares of the Grand Trunk Railway. But, there is a much more simple proposition, which perhaps will surprise the House and the public. I say in all seriousness that the government of Canada, which is controlling the Intercolonial Railway, the national system of railways, can obtain a lease of the Grand Trunk Railway for $1 a year, and the Canadian Pacific Railway for $1 a year, and that is in substance all the financial obligation involved. The government can lease these two great roads for $1 per year each and get a lease for 999 years, if it so desires. Such transactions are going on every day, But the government would have this to do, and I am not concealing that from the House and the country : it would have to assume the liabilities of these roads. But. who is assuming the liabilities to-day ? It is the people of Canada, for it is the traffic that sustains these roads. The bondholders,
the shareholders have not assumed them, but the people who use the roads are meeting these liabilities, and there is only one portion of these liabilities concerning which oue of these companies is in default, and that is the first shares of the Grand Trunk Railway. So far as the Canadian Pacific Railway is concerned, however, every dollar of liability in connection with it is being paid, and paid promptly, and yet the shareholders of that road would be willing today to lease that great enterprise, which has about $300,000,000 invested in it, to the people of Canada for $1 per year. That is a very simple proposition.
Are you authorized to make that offer ?

No, but if the hon. the Finance Minister (Hon. Mr. Fielding) will authorize my hon. friend to make inquiries,
I believe he will find that such an offer would be accepted. That is the way I meet the question. How will you raise the fifty million dollars? I ask the Minister of Finance : Have you two dollars a year to spare? If you have, you can control both the great railway enterprises of this country.
I rather prefer the method of purchase to the acquirement of the lines by lease. But, they can be purchased-both of these great lines-for less than $50,000,000 ; and that is no great difficult burden for Canada to assume at this day ; we have faced larger undertakings, and have carried them out successfully. So far as financial questions ard concerned, there is very little to prevent the country acquiring both roads. If we acquire the shares of these roads and assume all the responsibilities, the time will soon come when the liabilities can be converted so as to be a much smaller burden upon the people. Five per cent obligations can be converted into three per cent obligations-not all at once, of course, for some of the outstanding bonds have years to run ; and the sub-leases of the smaller sections also will not be renewable for years to come-but, as the bonds and leases mature, they can be converted at much smaller figures, and thus, without confusion the liability can be made to bear a much smaller percentage of interest and the traffic will be relieved of a very considerable burden.
How much liability should we have to assume ?

The total liability of the Canadian Pacific, so far as I can make out is $300,000,000. But that rests upon us to-day, and the people are paying the interest upon it in the traffic rates. But, though we bear this burden, we have nothing to say about the management of the road. When we pay the piper we should have the privilege of controlling the road.
We have had experience in running railways.

That is the point I was coming to, and that is the point of my amendment. And, on this point I expect the support of the Minister of Railways (Hon. Mr. Blair), and the Minister of Public Works (Hon. Mr. Tarte), because we have been informed in an official way, that they are prepared to extend the national system that we have to-day. I am prepared to extend that system if necessary, for our national railway is the best asset we have ; and I hope the country will extend it and expand it. My amendment is, in substance, that, as we have a national road, the first thing we ought to do is to de-politicalize its administration. We do not want politics in the Intercolonial Railway ; we do not want members of this House making appointments in connection with that road, or taking part in fixing its rates. I do not say that these things take place to-day, but I have heard that they do. The first step towards nationalizing the railways is to depoliticalize the railway we have. I do not mean to say that the Minister of Railways shall not sit in the House and be responsible to this House for that road. But what I do say, is that he should turn the administration of the railway over to first-class railway men who will allow no politics in the management. Is that possible? I believe it is ; and I am going to quote the opinion of a very prominent railway man on this point. I do not wish to give his name, but nearly all who hear me can guess who he is. He is said to be 4he biggest railway man we have in Canada. Happening to meet him, I said to him,
' What do you think of nationalizing the Canadian Pacific Railway and also including the Grand Trunk Railway, if necessary ?' He said: * It might be the best way out of it; but you cannot do that if you drag it into politics.' I then asked him,''Is it possible to administer the railway without dragging it into politics ?' His answer was, 1 It is.' He is a man of great force and rapidity of thought.; and he named over fifteen men. going from the maritime province, across the continent picking them out here and there. They were all first-class men. And he said, ' Take these fifteen men ; give them $1,000 a month as pay for going to a meeting once a week; let them appoint a general manager, the best man they can get, and pay him $50,000 a year if necessary ; and I believe you might run the Canadian railways with more economy and with better service to the country than by any other possible system.'
Give us his name.

You will have to take my word for it. Iam giving you merely a conversation, and would not care to take more liberties with it than to say the gentleman I refer to is a very prominent railway man of this country.
I think we know who it is as well as if he had been named.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext:
I suppose so. It was our friend Sir William Van Horne. In conversation the other night he said that if the road could be taken out of politics and administered by a board of the kind he had suggested, it would be possible to administer it successfully and with the greatest benefit to the people of Canada.
Now, as I pointed out the other day, we in Canada can carry out the proposition I have made, and do it very easily. We do not need any more legislation; we can do it under the legislation we have. We do not even need more money; we can do it with the money we have. In the United States, where there is a great movement in favour of the nationalization of railways, there are serious constitutional difficulties in the way. I have already said that I do not see how the American people could nationalize their railways without a revolution. But we have already started, and have only to continue in our present course, and, in a very short time all the roads can be taken over by the Dominion.
The proposition has been made, and the name of the Minister of Railways and Canals has been connected with it, of curing the railway grievances in this country by extending the Canadian national system-that is by nationalizing the Bootli line from Montreal to the Upper Lakes, and making some arrangement for a new government line clear across the continent. 1 shall feel obliged to support that if my own proposition is not realized. In the meantime I would say it is the most extravagant thing we could do, and, in one respect, only aggravates the situation. If you build another transcontinental line as a means of regulating the Canadian Pacific, you increase the burden that the traffic has to bear. Sooner than see this done. I would make every effort to take over the Canadian Pacific. How much would it cost to build a competing line across the continent?
I believe it would cost a hundred millions, and perhaps more ; and, when this is done, the country will have two lines to maintain, and. instead of getting lower rates may get higher. The true solution of the difficulty is to nationalize the Canadian Pacific-make it part of the Canadian government system. That can be done at small cost, and without aggravating the situation, while securing immediate relief to the people of this country.
Another thing that the government is committed to, and one that I must endorse if I cannot get government ownership of railways, is to attempt the removal of existing grievances by establishing a railway commission. If better is not done, I hope that commission will be established. But you must face the fact that a commission

will be constantly at war with the railways, and that war will be carried on at great expense. If you nationalize the railways, the whole energy of the commission can be given to managing the roads and securing the interests of the people. It you wish to avoid this constant warfare which the establishment of a railway commission would involve, you must have national ownership. In that respect, I wish to read other portions of this interview with Mr. Shaughnessy which bears directly on the point. Now, this is the most serious statement of all, and it is well worth the attention of the Minister of Railways and Canals :
' So much for the possibility of the control of American capitalists. What do you think, Mr. Shaughnessy, of the suggestion that in order to prevent this the government should itself acquire possession of the Canadian Pacific and other railways material to the prosperity of Canada, which are now owned by companies?' 'Well,' observed Mr. Shaughnessy, 'speaking quite frankly, I think it would be infinitely better, if the government intends to take up seriously the business of railroading, that the public money of this country should be invested in the acquisition of such railways as the Canadian Pacific and Grand Trunk than that it should be wasted in the subsidizing and construction of useless lines. fVe have had too much wasting of public money in the past for the building of railways which are not only in themselves useless, but are positively injurious, inasmuch as they cripple the lines which are already built. This is very pernicious, and, as I have said, it would be far preferable that the government should take over the existing lines than that they should build new ones to compete with them. You are at perfect liberty to quote me as having said this; I really do not think there is anything more I can say on the subject.'
Now, what are we up to ? We are up to this, that we have got to establish another government line, and maintain a railway commission, and have two great continental roads in the service of the country, or we have got to nationalize the one we have. There is no other way out of it. There is great expenditure ahead of you, and the Minister of Railways and Canals is almost committed by his newspaper friends to another transcontinental, line, and to a railway commission in constant warfare with the roads ; either that or you have got to nationalize the road you have. That is what we are up against, and that is another point to which I desire to direct the attention of the country.
Now, can we nationalize railways l Is it a foolish idea ? What are the facts in regard to that ? Our fellow colonists, as we call them, in the southern hemisphere, in Australia, in New Zealand, have nationalized their railways, and they would not change their policy to-morrow under any circumstances. This is a great fact that comes home to us. In some European countries the railways have nearly all been nationalized. In Germany there are two
kinds of railways, state-owned and private-owned ; but the tendency is to take over every private-owned railway there. In Austria and Hungary they have the best transportation for passengers in the world, and the cheapest, and it is because the government controls the railways. It is the same in almost every other European country. They have state-owned railways, and the people do not for a moment think of abandoning the system and going back to private corporations. Public opinion is growing in favour of state-owned railways ; and in England to-day one of the few ways in which the British manufacturer will be able to meet foreign competition is b.V having lower freight rates, and the way they wish to attain that object is by the state taking over the roads.
Now, Sir, this railway question will never be smaller than it is. Delay only aggravates the situation. Let us never forget that it is the traffic that pays for and maintains the railway, not the shareholders, or the bondholders, or the administration of the road. In other words, the people who use the roads support them ; why should they not control them ? Canada can buy the controlling shares of the Canadian Pacific Railway for less than thirty million dollars, and she can buy the controlling shares of the Grand Trunk Railway for less than twenty million dollars. Canada can own and control both roads, subject to the mortgages on them, for less than fifty million dollars paid for their controlling shares. Canada can lease and secure control of the Grand Trunk Railway and the Canadian Pacific Railway for $1 each a year, on undertaking to guarantee the shareholders who now have the control, less than 4 per cent on the face value of the shares. The stock of the Canadian Pacific Railway guaranteed by government at 3 per cent would be above par, and that is what the shareholders desire.
The proposition of public ownership in its simplest form lies in assuming the liabilities, guaranteeing the interest and dividends, and leasing each road at a nominal rental of $1 a year. Surely the Minister of Finance (Hon. Mr. Fielding) has two $1 bills at his disposal. As a matter of fact, the traffic of the roads is now doing all these things, with the single exception of some shares of the Grand Trunk Railway. Rut. with government ownership the extravagant competition for traffic would cease, the working expenses incident to rivalry would be reduced, the existing obligations in the way of rents on leases of road would be absorbed, interest on bonds and preferred stock could be gradually reduced, and that very materially, and in a thousand ways savings could be effected in works unnecessary to a co-operative railway and a cooperative rail and water system. Better wages could and would be paid to the smaller number of men, but the wages bill

of a consolidated system would be mueb smaller.
And these railways once consolidated would be the complement of all our other public works, our canals, our harbour improvements, our river improvements. Today the railways have antagonized the national railway system of this country. I also speak within the truth when I say that the railways of Canada for years did their best to delay the deepening of the canals of this country, and they succeeded in it ; and I believe they are trying to interfere to-day in every way possible with the utilization of these canals. But if once the government owned the railways, the canals and the railways would then be complementary of each other, and would work harmoniously for the benefit of the Canadian people.
I have heard it said that if we start out to nationalize the railways by purchase, the shareholders would run up the price. Now, that is not a fact, the converse would actually happen. As soon as it became known that Canada proposed to nationalize the railways, there would be a competition between the Grand Trunk Railway and the Canadian Pacific Railway as to who would sell or lease first ; and if the majority of the stock of either roads was to be acquired, there would be a rush and a competition between the shareholders to sell to the government. Neither road, nor any of the shareholders of that road, would wish to be left out ; and instead of the price of stocks going up they would naturally come down by reason of this competition. No doubt that may seem a peculiar statement, but it is one I am prepared to stand by.
In the supreme struggle which is now going on between the United States and Canada, between New York, Boston and Portland on the one side, and the St. Lawrence route and Canadian ports on the other, can we for one moment allow our great railway system to fall under the control of the great United States combine, which has its centre in the American ports of New York, Boston and Baltimore ? Can we afford that ns a Canadian people ? Can we afford to allow great interests in American ports to control our own railway system on which we have spent so much money ? Some gentlemen think they see a great many lions in the way of government ownership. I admit there are difficulties, but I think they can be met and overcome. We have to retrace our steps, but in doing so we will be doing something that I believe the people of Canada desire us to do.
The greatest curse in politics to-day is the corruption wrought and exercised by corporations in the municipal, provincial and federal spheres. The corruption of corporations even threatens our courts. The political corruption of a political administration of a railway is a flea-bite compared to the corruption of the people and legisla-

tures by corporations. A corporation never dies, because it is a past-master in corruption. That is not the case with individuals. People say they are opposed to government railways on account of the political corruption which would exist in their management. Sir, I am not afraid of that. The political corruption that I am afraid of in this country is that which has been exercised by great corporations. There is no comparison between the two. I grant you there will be some corruption and there will be some maladministration, but that is nothing to compare with the greater corruption that threatens this whole country by reason of the power of these great corporations.
An intelligent democracy like ours ought to be equal to cope with any problem that arises. A people who prides themselves on their ability for self-government ought to be equal to the further responsibilities of selfownership of great franchises. Surely if we are competent to govern ourselves we ought to go forward and put in practice this proposition of assuming control of the great railroads of this country. We are not less able in the solution of our economic problem, not less competent to do what our fellows in Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, or what the nations of Europe have done. Here is the next proposition which I wish to submit; you cannot settle a twentieth century problem with nineteenth century ideas. This great problem is a twentieth century problem and the solution of it is in national ownership and not in the practices that have been observed in this House and in the Railway Committee of this House for the past thirty years. What is the problem before the railway manager as the roads are run to-day ? The problem before Mr. Hays, or Mr. Shaughnessy is : How can we administer this railway so ns to secure the best returns for the men who have invested their money in it ? The problem before the manager of a national system of railways is : How can I run this railway in the best interests of the people who have to support it ? These propositions are two entirely different ones ; the man who is working for the government has much higher work in his hands. All he has to do is to see what he can do for the people, but with Mr. Hays and Mr. Shaughnessy nine-tenths of their time is taken up dealing with questions of competition and finding out how they can make a profit for the shareholders and bondholders of the road. Instead of public ownership of railways tending to demoralize the people, I believe it would compel every man to take a deeper interest in public affairs and to use his ballot more conscientiously. Instead of public ownership entrenching a party in power it would tend to effect more rapid changes in parties. Patronage and responsibility are a source of weakness not of strength to party. This is the way I understand the idea of selfgovernment in this country. If every man

has an Interest in the railways of the country he would take a greater interest in public questions, and instead of railway administration being a bar to good government I think it would help it. The difference between a private trust controlling all roads of a country and state ownership is this: The trust gets all the benefit of consolidation, economical management and the saving effected in not having to duplicate existing lines and takes the bulk of these benefits to itself. A state-owned system receives all these benefits and economies and gives them to the people. A trust antagonizes or may antagonize a nation ; a state-owned system is bound to be patriotic.
Science, genius, enterprise, public spirit, utilizing the thousand and one imprescriptible legacies of the past, are constantly striving to better the lot of mankind, and up to the present time the wealthy, the ambitious, the trusts, the combines, the corporations have tried to corner and to restrict, have succeeded in cornering, in restricting the use of these discoveries, of these gifts to man made by genius, intellect, enterprise and public spirit.
Now, Mr. Speaker, I have taken up a good deal of the time of the House, but I do trust that I have brought clearly before the House and the country this question of government ownership. I trust that the question as brought up by me will receive the attention of the House and the government and in doing what I have done I have only discharged my duty. I am one of those who believe in and have every confidence in the Canadian people. I believe they are equal to the task of owning and controlling the railways of this country. I am not one of those who cast a slur upon the honour of my fellow-countrymen in Canada. It is said up and down Canada by the great corporations owning the railways of this country that the Canadian people are unfit to own railways, that they are dishonest, unpatriotic and corruptible. I do not believe that ; I agree with what Senator Hoar of Massachusetts said who, discussing the question of trusts in the United States declared : I believe that the great bulk of the American people are honest, patriotic and incorruptible. I believe the same of the Canadian people, but the men who own these great trusts in Canada to-day have a paid propaganda, a propaganda that is filling the newspapers of this country with the idea that we are a corrupt lot of people, that the government is corrupt and that in no way could a railway be honestly administered by the people. I repudiate that slander on my fellow-countrymen, on the government and legislature of this country. I believe we can do these things. I believe this is the work before us now, and that is the reason why I have brought this question up here today. I have not brought it up to embarrass the government, or the House, nor have I brought it up to embarrass my own friends,
as has been said, but I have brought it up so as to direct public attention to it and if possible to induce the government, before they go into a system to which they seem to be committed, namely, of extending the Intercolonial Railway, to first try to make a reasonable effort to nationalize all the railway lines of this country. If they do that they will be doing something patriotic ; they will meet with the support of the people of this country, but if they do not do it there will be a party arise in this country and arise in this House that will make the nationalization of the railways in Canada its main plank and if this party and these men do come forth I believe that when they make an appeal to the people of Canada they will receive an overwhelming mandate to nationalize these roads. Mr. Speaker, I beg to move :
That all the words after the word ' That ' be left out, and the following added instead thereof:
' In order that the government railway system of Canada may be used to the best possible advantage of the people by being a substantial check on the freight charges of railways owned by private corporations, and in order that the government system may give the public the most efficient service, this House is of the opinion that the administration thereof should be freed of all political influence or Interference.'

Mr. Speaker, 1 was in hopes that we would have heard a word or two from the right lion, gentleman (Sir Wilfrid Laurier) or the Minister of Railways and Canals (Hon. Mr. Blair) in regard to the matter which has been brought before the House by my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean) who has just taken his seat. I think, in the first place, that the thanks of this House and the country are due to the hon. gentleman for having brought this matter to the attention of the House and the country, because, while there may be some of us who would not go so far as the hon. gentleman has gone in his remarks in regard to this matter, there can he no doubt whatever that this is a subject which should invite the earnest attention of the government. We know that the government of this country is at the present time engaged in carrying on a business which is ordinarily carried on in this country by railway corporations, and we know that it is carrying on that business in competition, to a certain extent, at least, with private corporations. Now, my hon. friend's motion is perhaps not so wide as the remarks which he has addressed to the House in regard to it. His motion is that the administration of our railways should be freed from political influence or interference. If I rightly understand what the hon. gentleman intends by the language which he has used in this motion it seem3 to me that there could hardly he two opinions in the House in respect to the desirability of the principle which he has laid down. The Intercolonial Railway is run as a department of the government. It is, I

presume, and always has been, more or less, subject to the same party political influence which affects other departments of the government in this country. Now, I suppose, that none of us could doubt that if the administration of the Intercolonial Railway, or indeed of any department of the government, were freed from that political influence and interference which are sometimes not conducive to the public interest it would be a distinct gain to the country. The government railways of this country stand in a different position from other departments of government in that respect. For example the Post Office Department deals with the carriage of mails throughout the country, and it is provided by statute that any person undertaking to enter into competition with it shall be guilty of an offence. When you come to deal with railways there is a different condition of affairs. Look at the administration of the Intercolonial Railway. It is more or less subject to what is called political influence and political interference. I am using the language which my hon. friend used in his motion. Let us suppose that the Canadian Pacific Railway, or the Bank of Montreal, or any great manufacturing concern in this country were to undertake to carry on its business subject to political influence and interference of this kind. Does any one suppose for a moment that the business of such a corporation would not be greatly hindered under such conditions? Does any one suppose that equally good results could be arrived at by any great Canadian corporation if it were hampered in such a way V Therefore, so far as the motion tends to prevent political influence and interference in connection with the administration of the Intercolonial Railway, we ought all be heartily in accord with and I presume that the Minister of Railways (Hon. Mr. Blair) would be the first person to join in the wish for such a desirable consummation as that.
When you come to go further and to deal with the means by which you shall attain such an end, and with the question of nationalizing the railways of Canada the House perhaps may not be prepared to express an opinion. Since my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean) brought this matter to the attention of the House, I have endeavoured to examine in some slight way the mode in which other colonies have dealt with this matter, and I find that in the Australasian colonies and in New Zealand, the railways are for the most part dealt with by a commission, and in these colonies the freedom of the administration of the railways from political influence has been found to be productive of very beneficial results. I am not prepared to say that we should at once follow the example of these colonies. We have a very much larger problem to deal with in Canada than arises in the Australian colonies Mr. BORDEN (Halifax).
because we have about 17,000 miles of railways (of which about 1,500 are government railways) and the paid up capital of the railway lines in Canada runs up to nearly $1,000,000,000. Therefore, when we speak about nationalizing the railways of Canada, or when we speak about dealing with the Intercolonial Railway by means of a commission, we have a pretty large problem to consider, and we possibly have difficulties which were not present in the experience of the colonies to which I have referred. I think, however, that the matter has very properly been brought to the attention of the House, and it is a matter upon which the government of this country should have a policy. There are many matters as to which the government has made investigations during the past five years, and on which the public money of this country has been expended, which are very much less worthy of the consideration of the government and of the country than the matter to which my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean) has drawn the attention of parliament. While it is a matter in which I agree we should not move hastily, a matter which we should take time to consider ; it is nevertheless a matter which the government should take into earnest and prompt consideration. I believe that the country demands that the government should do so. I am prepared to support the motion giving it the meaning which I have attached to it ; not dealing with it as necessarily involving the appointing of a commission, not dealing for the present with the question of the nationalization of our railways or the means by which that will be accomplished, if it is ever accomplished, but dealing with what I understand to be the main proposition laid down by my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean), namely : ' that the administration of government railways in Canada should be free from party political influence and interference.
Is that all there is in the resolution ?
That is all.
That is what I understand.

I have no desire to cast any reflection upon the procedure of my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean), because I am quite convinced that his disposition is to treat the House in a bona fide spirit on this question. It is, I am sure, not his intention to ask us to vote upon a resolution to which he has not addressed the attention of the House, and in support of which he has made no argument. Indeed, if his remarks has even a remote relation to the subject-matter of the resolution, I am unable to see it, but perhaps that is my misfortune. My hon. friend (Mr. Maclean)

puzzles me. He will, I think, confess that he himself is puzzled because if his argument proves anything it proves that the best policy for this country is that the railways should be absolutely and entirely controlled by the government of the day and become government property. The hon. gentleman (Mr. Maclean) is a sincere advocate of the nationalization of railways, but does it not occur to him that as he has presented the question to-day it is more an academic question than a practical one. We are met in this parliament as practical men for a practical purpose, but my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean) has not recognized that fact in the course which he has taken on this question. He has not offered us any suggestion as to the manner in which this policy is to be carried out, and when he tells us that it would cost five thousand millions and two dollars to acquire the Canadian Pacific Railway and Grand Trunk Railway systems, it would seem to be necessary that he should follow that up by at least giving us some hint as to how we should finance an undertaking of such magnitude.
speakername: The MINISTER OE RAILWAYS AND CANALS (Hon. Mr. Blair).

speechtext: Two dollars will do it.

When my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean) says that two dollars will do it, his statement is a convincing proof that he is not looking on this question from a practical point of view. Inasmuch as all of his argument has been of that character and as it did not touch the resolution at all, I apprehend that when the matter is duly discussed he will withdraw his motion rather than have the public suppose that we are voting on a motion which might lead those who read his speech to think was the real question before the House, when as a matter of fact it deals with an entirely different matter. The hon. gentleman's motion deals entirely with the government railway system, and on a careful study of its wording he will find that there is involved in it a distinct implication that a government system of railways is not a wise system, that it is attended with disadvantageous results, that there is a tendency that the rates on a government railway will be higher than on another railway, because the government railway is subject to political influence.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: That the rates will be.lower.

No, higher ; because my hon. friend-his language, if it means anything implies this-suggests that you ought to get this government system of railways freed from political influence or control in order that rates may not be maintained, but that the tariff of rates may be diminished. I am not, I think,
misinterpreting the words of the hon. gentleman's motion, which is distinctly and explicitly pointed against the policy of government ownership and control of railways altogether. If it means anything, it means that. It means that you must not own or control railways, because they will be subject to political influence. Can you imagine a railway owned by a government which is not subject to political influence ? Is there a possibility of such a thing existing ? I cannot conceive of it, and I am sure my hon. friend cannot conceive of it. Why do I say that it is under political influence ? Because, being a property of the people, the trusteeship of it must be in the government of the day supported by the representatives of the people. Its very basis and foundation is that it is under the control and supervision of the people, and that control and supervision can only be exercised in a political way. Will my hon. friend suggest to me how it is conceivable that a government railway system can be managed without the management largely partaking-and I am putting it in the mildest possible form -of a political character ?
Now, I am not speaking entirely without having had some opportunity of gathering information as to the experience of others on this question. We can turn, as my hon. friend the leader of the opposition has done, to the results of the experiment in the various Australasian colonies, and what do we find there ? They started out building and owning all their railways. They had probably felt some dissatisfaction with the extent to which political influence was operating in connection with the maintenance and administration of those railways, and they concluded that it would be a wise policy to change the system, and they changed the system. Take the case of New Zealand, for instance, which was largely followed by the other provinces. Down to 1887, the province of New Zealand owned its railways as a government system, controlled and managed exclusively and directly through the administration. In 1887 they changed that system and adopted a commission. Their idea was that they would have all the advantages belonging to government ownership without any of the incidental disadvantages consequent upon political interference or control. After trying that svstem from 1891, down to 1894, they found that after all they had not overcome the disadvantages which they had hoped to be able to overcome. They found that political influence still existed. They had not found that it was so very harmful under the direct administrative system prior to 1887 ; but they found that it still prevailed ; and in 1894 ' they made a change in the character of their commission, and tried that change down to 1S97. The change did not seem to suit their purpose any better; and in 1897 the policy of the govern-

meat took a marked advance-or a retrograde step, as some might perhaps regard it. They went back practically to direct government ownership and control through a minister of the Crown ; and they did that distinctly on the ground that they had not freed themselves from any of the disadvantages incident to government ownership and control, but had incurred a very great many disadvantages which were injurious to the country as a whole, under the system of a railway commission. One of tlie things they complained of especially in respect of the management of a railway commission was that the commission was not open to the pressure from the people and from parliament and from the government which it ought to be open to-that there was not the same broad and liberal policy maintained by the commission that would have been maintained if the railways had continued under the direct management and control of the government, and that the commission was not in close touch with the people and ready to yield to the people's wishes. They complained that tlie rates were maintained against the public interest to the disadvantage of business, prejudicial to the establishment of industries and against tlie spirit of enterprise which was abroad in the country. So they have practically gone back to direct control through a minister of the Crown.
The same results have attended the experiments of the other provinces in the same directions. In Tasmania up to 1891, the railways were being operated by companies. By an Act of 1891, all government railways were vested in a minister. The Governor in Council appoints the general manager, who acts under the direction of the minister. In Victoria, a system of three independent commissioners was introduced in 1883, but in 1891, there was practically a return to government control, the minister being made the head of the commission, and having a dual vote. By an Act of 1S96, the form of the commission was changed from three to one. and a commissioner was obliged to act simply as an adviser to the head of the department. In New South Wales, by an Act of 1858, tlie commissioners of railways held office during pleasure; but in 1888 three independent commissioners were appointed, as in Queensland and Victoria. This condition of things has since been changed so that the commissioners are unable to take any steps or adopt any policy without the consent of the Governor in ' Council. In South Australia, by an Act of 1858, a commission was created and commissioners appointed to continue in office during pleasure In 1887 a clia-ge was made, and three independent commissioners were appointed In 1894 one commissioner was appointed iii lieu of the three, and the Minister of Railways in the government was vested with
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: power to decide all questions wherever any differences of opinion arose. So that you see that while all these experiments have been going on in these other provinces, whose conditions to some extent resemble ours, the changes which have been made within the last ten or fifteen years have been all in the direction of revesting in the government the direct control and management of these railways. In the discussions which have taken place upon these various proposals from time to time, I have seen no difference of opinion expressed upon this point, that no matter how the government railways might be managed-whether the control be invested in a commission or remain in a minister-it was impossible to divest the administration from political influences and control. These would make themselves felt under any circumstances. I am quite sure that my hon. friend, when he asks this House to subscribe to the proposition that we should free the administration of these railways from government control-
Political.

Political control rather, he practically declares himself in favour of freeing the railways from government control entirely, and divesting the government of the control they now possess, both as owning and as operating the railway system.
I think, therefore, as far as I can judge, that the motion of my hon. friend is not one which can commend itself to the House, and I trust he will not press it to a vote.
He must himself admit that it does not reflect the conclusion which one is entitled to draw from the argument he presented to the House. His argument was not in support of the proposal embodied in his motion, but on the contrary directly antagonistic to it.
While I am not prepared to say that the ideal condition, so far as the management of railways in Canada, and possibly in any country is concerned, might not be that these railways should be entirely under the control of the government-be owned and managed by the government or under direct government supervision-while that might well be said to be an ideal condition, we have not this question before us in any such practical shape, it has not been presented to us in any such form, as would justify us in passing upon so large and momentous a question as that at present.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext:
I listened, Mr. Speaker, with a great deal of interest to the remarks with which my hon friend from East York (Mr. Maclean) introduced his resolution, and I thought he was doing bravely until he read the terms of the resolution itself. I am one of those who believe that tl*e time has come when the people should get a certain portion back or

that which belongs to them, and that it is time we should call a halt in the rolling up of these immense fortunes by a few individuals. The number of people who believe that much of the wealth which should go into the hands of the people generally is being diverted by corporations, and particularly by large railway corporations, is increasing largely, and I listened with favour to the remarks of my hon. friend, and would support to the best of my ability any scheme calculated to lessen the burdens that rest upon the producers in this country, and give a larger share of the benefits to the great mass of wage-earners. But the resolution is entirely different from the language in which it was introduced. The question of state ownership does not present itself at all in the resolution, nor do we find in it any condemnation of monopolies. The only thing we find in the resolution is this, that the hon. gentleman took advantage of a sentiment that is strongly growing in this country in order to disseminate the idea that the present government is not successfully carrying on the affairs of the Intercolonial Railway, and that we could only hope for successful management by vesting one-half of it in the hands of Conservatives. That is all there is in the resolution. It does not call on us to approve of government ownership, but simply to condemn the present management of the Intercolonial Railway by the Hon. Mr. Blair, and to declare that everything would be bright and rosy if he would only associate with himself some good red hot Tory. I am not prepared to support that resolution, because there is not the remotest connection between it and the speech with which my hon. friend introduced it. I am with him when he declares himself in favour of bettering the condition of the mass of the people. I am with him when he expresses his desire to prevent millionaires from rolling up fortunes and going to distant lands and seeking honours in distant lands by becoming Sirs and Lords and Dukes ; but I am not prepared to condemn the present management of the Intercolonial Railway. I do not want, nor do the people want, hon. gentlemen opposite, for years to come, to have any share in its management.

i merely wish to say, Mr. Speaker, that while I subscribe entirely to this resolution, which I cannot conceive can be controverted by any one, I am not prepared to accept in their entirety the views expressed by my hon. friend in his very able address, concerning the great danger which by common consent threatens the railways of this country. I cannot understand how it can be possible, after the discussions we have heard in this House, for any man to uphold the principle that the administration of the Intercolonial Railway, or any railway controlled by the government, should not be free from political interference or influence.
Why, that doctrine has been accepted on all hands. We have had experience in the province of Quebec of the danger and evils of political influence-not governmental control-but political influence in the management of railways and of how dangerous that influence may become. My hon. friend opposite, the right hon. leader of the government and hon. gentlemen who have followed political events in the province ot Quebec, and the results of the ownership by the government of railways there, will surely not fail to subscribe to the proposition advocated by my hon. friend the member for Bast York (Mr. Maclean) that any such plan as he advocated to-day, under the name of nationalization of railways, must be preceded by the freeing of government railways from that political influence and interference, as he properly terms it, which by the consent of everybody has always been so detrimental.
My hon. friend took occasion to refer to the great danger which threatens us, the existence of which he ably showed by the quotations he made, namely, the danger of the absorption of our railways by foreign capitalists, few in number, who would use those railways, built up largely by us, for the benefit of their own country and for their own selfish ends. That danger is well known. We all know that we are threatened with it, and we had the right to expect some expression of opinion from the government benches upon so momentous a question. Have they not thought it over V Are they not able, even if they cannot give us a remedy for that dreadful evil, to show us that they have thought it over, or that they intend to think it over ? Apparently they are not. If my hon. friend the leader of the opposition had not risen to express his own views, we would have had no expression at all from the government on this question. Why ? My hon. friend from East York has spoken to us of the project ot the hon. Minister of Public Works (Hon. Mr. Tarte) to extend the Intercolonial Railway-which we all know he prolonged from Ste. Rosalie to Montreal at considerable sacrifice to the taxpayers of Canada. He has the project, my hon. friend informs me, of carrying that railway as far as the Pacific. We all know the great weight my hon. friend the Minister of Public Works- and I am pleased to recognize it-has in the councils of the government. We can well understand, if what we have heard in the province of Quebec is true, that the Minister of Railways, clever though he may be, after his experience in Paris last summer, when he went over
I was not in Paris last summer.
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext:
A strong delegation of the government went over to influence the Minister of Public Works ; but we all know how that hon.. gentleman downed



them on that occasion. We can understand why they should now hesitate to express an opinion on any subject coming before them until they know what the Minister of Public Works thinks about it. The Minister of Railways and Canals tells us that there is no connection whatever, between the motion which appears upon the paper and the views discussed by my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean). He thinks that if we are going to nationalize the railways, it is useless to discuss the proposition, even as a primary proposition, that the government railways should be free-not from political control, he came down to that in closing his remarks, but from that political influence and interference which has always and admittedly been so detrimental to the management of railways. If we are to accept the astounding proposition of the Minister of Railways, that political influence and interference must always exist; there is no remedy. Surely, the hon. minister is a pessimist in that regard ; surely, there is some hope that the people of Canada will see to it that, in time, and with patience, that evil is removed. But, No, says the minister, that political influence and interference must be associated with government control. As to that, we know that the railways in those countries in which they are under government control are free from that obnoxious influence and interference. We have only to open the books which treat of that subject to convince ourselves that there is no such thing under European control of railways as political influence and interference, with all the evils that those two words imply ; and we have proof that in British dependencies, where railways are owned by the government, efforts have been made, and with success, to obviate this evil. Let me quote a word from Larrabee, a well-known authority on railway questions. On page 65, speaking of the railways in Victoria, he says :
All lines are under control of a board so constituted as to be entirely removed from political influence. Several roads were originally owned by private companies, but all of them were acquired by the colonial government, the last one in 1878.
Hole, on the nationalization of railways, page 226, says :
New South Wales has adopted the system of putting its railways under the control of three experienced railway commissioners, of which Mr. Eddy, an expert from England, was the head. The political element in New South Wales proved itself quite as objectionable as in Victoria.
Here, Sir, are two countries similarly situated to our own, where, more hopeful than the Minister of Railways and Canals, they did not start with the idea that political influence and interference in the management of railways, is the inevitable consequence of government ownership, and where they have succeeded. Therefore, I ask, is it Mr. MONK.
not possible to adopt the principle at least, that political interference and influence is totally distinct from government control ? That is what my hon. friend (Mr. Maclean) is advocating-government control of railways. Even if political interference under government management cannot be done away with at once, at least we should work in that direction ; and that is the opinion of the country. Now, I said that, though quite in favour of the proposition of my hon. friend from East York, I did not entirely agree with him as to the means of carrying it out. Of course, if, as the government says, no danger threatens us, if it be true, as the Minister of Railways and Canals tells us, that this is merely an academic question, we are losing our time. But that is not the opinion of the country. Have we no remedy other than the acquisition of these two vast lines ?
