For my part, I am not prepared to suggest another remedy ; but I think that the remedy proposed by my hon. friend, and so skilfully defended by him, is fraught with great danger at the present moment. The danger is one to our finances, and I think that the existence of that political influence and interference, which I, for my part, condemn, constitutes another danger, should we carry out the project of acquiring these railways. We are not in the same position as the Congress of the United States. Their powers of legislation, in a case analogous to this one-I imagine, without having gone fully into the question-would be extremely limited by the constitution. Our parliament on the other hand, is supreme. My hon. friend (Mr. Maclean) has referred to the acquisition of Suez canal shares, one of the masterly strokes of Mr. Disraeli's policy. But, in carrying out that policy, the great English statesman was acquiring a property entirely beyond the control of the parliament of Great Britain. I am exposing merely a primary view of the subject before us, but would point out that we are dealing with two immense enterprises that we have built up, I might almost say with our own money, and which we maintain. We have built these railways for what purpose ? We have built them in order to develop this immense inheritance with which Providence has blessed us. But now, if I am to accept all that has been stated by my hon. friend, who has so carefully studied the subject, we are in the presence of the danger involved in the possible acquisition of these two great roads by foreigners, by a syndicate composed of a few men who have no interest in Canada, and who desire to make these railways, which, I think, we can fairly consider the railways of the people of Canada, useful in carrying out their own private aims, and to benefit a country which is not our country. Under these circumstances, I ask myself if there is no remedy in legislation ? I ask if parliament, being supreme, and having in view what has been done by the people of

Canada towards the construction of these lines, and being face to face with a danger which is recognized by all, except, perhaps, by the Minister of Railways and Canals, but realized, I think, by my bon. friend the Minister of Public Works-being face to face, I say, with an imminent danger, is it possible that parliament, whose powers are so great, can provide no remedy ? I would be inclined to say that before this imminent evil falls upon us, before the evil of foreign ownership or foreign control of these lines is actually realized, there must be some remedy in legislation.
Is there not foreign ownership already ? Is not a large portion of the Canadian Pacific Railway stock owned by Germans ?
speakername: The MINISTER OF RAILWAYS AND CANALS.

speechtext: My hon. friend seems to be just wakening up to the danger which threatens us. Everybody knows that the capital which built the Canadian Pacific Railway, and the Grand Trunk Railway too, so far as I know, was largely furnished by people who live in Europe. But surely there is a difference between that and the ever increasing action, the devouring action, if I may use that expression, of these five, or six, or eight men whom the member for East York (Mr. Maclean) named here the other day, and who are known by all men who take any interest in that subject. We are face to face, I say, with the danger of a few wealthy Americans obtaining control of the great railway lines ; and that is a very different thing from a certain amount of European capital being invested in our railways with no other object than of earning a dividend on that capital. I am not going to take up the time of the House by indicating particularly any legislative remedy. In the first place, I do not know of any ; but I do submit to this House that this parliament is all-powerful. We are in the presence of a great danger, and surely we have the power in this parliament, without being obliged to buy over again these lines which we have built largely with our own money, to discover some legislative remedy which will enable us to ward off that impending danger, and to keep these great railway lines in our own control, for the purpose of developing our own country, instead of allowing them to be used for the development of the neighbouring republic.

It is to be regretted that the hon. member for East York (Mr. Maclean) has brought forward so big a subject, one of such vital concern to the people of Canada at large, on so small a motion. I agree with almost every word that has fallen from the lips of the hon. member for Jacques Cartier (Mr. Monk) ; but I must say at once that I cannot vote for this motion as it stands, though I fully concur on the main principle 6i
that there might be government control without political interference. I cannot agree with the proposition of the Minister of Railways and Canals, that government control of railways and political interference with government control of railways are one and the same thing. They are two things in most civilized countries, and I hope the time is not distant when they will be two things in Canada. But the concrete proposition contained in this motion is not a practicable one at present. The reason is trivial, but it is true all the same. We know that one party who was in power for a great many years never attempted to cure that evil, and used the political advantages of government control of railways to their fullest extent. It is quite natural, therefore, that the other party now being in power would likewise be unwilling to take steps to cure that evil while they have a chance to take their revenge. But when an equilibrium has been established in the administration of the Intercolonial Railway, when the blue blood and the red blood have been mixed up in equal proportions, I think the proposition of the hon. member for East York will likely receive more favourable consideration from the members on this side of the House.
But, to my mind, that is a very small question compared with the greater one which has been so well dealt with by the hon. member for Jacques Cartier. I am in total disagreement with the Minister of Railways and Canals when he calls this an academic question. I think it is the most practical and vital question that is before the people of Canada to-day, or is likely to come up for the next few years. It is no argument against the proposition of the hon. member for East York to say that the capital of the Canadian Pacific Railway, or of any other big railway in Canada, is in the hands of foreign shareholders. For my part, and I think I express the opinion of most Canadians. I have no objection to foreign capital coming into this country to build railways, or to establish any other great enterprises, provided such capital, the moment it is invested on Canadian soil and receives the protection of the Canadian government, becomes Canadian capital for the benefit of the Canadian people. I have no objection to as many foreigners as you like being shareholders of the Canadian Pacific Railway so long as that railway is controlled by the parliament of Canada ; but I have a great objection to Americans coming in here and obtaining the control of the Canadian Pacific Railway and making it a mere branch of an American railway system.
Now, as to what legislation we should adopt, I do not propose to indicate any at this time ; I did not rise to say to the Minister of Railways and Canals that he should do this or that he should do that. I have sufficient confidence in the business ability

of that lion, gentleman, as well as In the clear-sightedness of his colleagues, to believe that when they give their earnest attention to this question they will be able to discover a remedy ; I have no doubt that they will look upon it from a Canadian point of view. Sir, I have been for some months past branded as a disloyal citizen ; but as a Canadian, considering this question one of the greatest national problems which has ever been brought before this parliament, I say now to ministers of the Crown and members of parliament, that if they do not give it their serious consideration they will be committing a national crime. The moment the Canadian Pacific Railway or the Grand Trunk Railway become a branch of an American railway system, controlled by an American syndicate whose primary interest will still be in the American republic, that moment will Canada be in danger. Even though this American syndicate had for its whole object a profit on their capital invested in Canadian railways. If they find out that they can increase their revenue and increase their dividends by wiping out the political line which exists at present between the United States and Canada, they will find means to do so. They will find capital enough not only to buy out our railways, but they will find sufficient capital to buy newspapers in Canada ; and, without insulting the members of this House, I may say they will probably find means to incline to their wishes and their schemes some of the representatives of the people of Canada whom they will be able to secure. We have seen other legislatures influenced by capitalists, we have seen other statesmen who have been influenced by foreign money.
Speak for yourself.

The hon. gentleman is a little too sensitive; I meant no personal allusion to him. I have enough respect for the hon. gentleman to tell him that he is wrong in considering my remark as personal. But I wish to say, Sir, that while this parliament is composed of good men, they are no better than the average statesmen of any other country ; and we know that in a legislature it sometimes takes but very few voices to change the balance of power. When strong attention is not given by the representatives of the people to questions of this kind, when they rely simply upon the leaders of their party to frame their policy and then go on blindly and vote as the whip of their party will tell them to vote; it might take no very big amount of money and very few men to put this country into the most dangerous position that it could be put into. Therefore, Sir, whilst I am certainly not going to vote for the proposition of the hon. member of East York (Mr. Maclean) because I think in its concrete form it is not opportune, I say that we have a duty to perform here ; and it is to give warning not

only to the members of this government but to all the members of this House, whether Conservative or Liberal, whether friends or opponents of the Canadian Pacific Railway because, after all, these are small questions compared with the real issue. It is our duty as representatives of the Canadian people to look at this big question from the real national point of view, not to have any prejudice about it, not to make up our minds hastily that it will be solved either by government ownership of railways or by some other means but to realize that the question is so important that we should give our personal attention to it. We should think of the future of our country, and of the great sacrifices that have been made in the building of our railways. We would not be equal to our position, we would not fulfil our duties to the people if we did not give to this question the attention which it deserves and I know, or I hope I know, that the government of Canada will give proper attention to it, and that, on some future occasion, we will be able to hear from them an expression of opinion which will resolve itself into a practical result when the danger will really come upon us.

Mr. Speaker the hon. member for Labelle (Mr. Bourassa) thinks that we should wait. He says that there is a great danger, that the danger is threatening but that we should wait until that danger has really come upon us and then he is confident that the government will do the right thing.

If the hon. gentleman (Mr. Wallace) will allow me : I do not say that we should wait. On the contrary, I say that we should prepare at once and be ready to meet the danger with a practical remedy when it comes.

I understood the hon. gentleman's last sentence was that we should wait until the danger comes. He also says that one of his objections to the motion made by the hon. member for East York (Mr. Maclean) is that when the Conservative party were in power for many years they had the control of affairs, that they had the patronage and that we should wait until the Liberal party have been in power for a number of years more so that they may even up. I think it will be conceded by every one who has watched affairs that they have done remarkably well in that direction during the past five years and have evened up, that they have dismissed officials and appointed others with remarkable facility. The hon. member for South Brant (Mr. Heyd) has the same grievance. He acknowledges that a great evil is threatening this country, that dangers are around us. He says the wealth of the country is being converted into the hands of individuals and corporations and that we should be on the alert, that we should be prepared

to defend the interests of the people, yet, he says the same thing as the hon. member for Labelle. He says that some red hot Tory may obtain a position and therefore he will oppose the motion. That is his only argument against it. I suppose he thinks there are a great many red hot Grits hungry still that have not been given an opportunity of feeding at the government trough who will have to be satisfied before the interests of the country can be looked after.
Now, Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Railways and Canals (Hon. Mr. Blair) told us this afternoon that the motion of my hon. friend for East York means that the government must not own railways nor control them. I do not think it could be fairly given that interpretation. The government must always control the larger politics of the country and the policy of the government might be very much different from the policy that would be promulgated by a commission. A commission might be endeavouring to make the road a financial success, on the same lines as the railways that are owned by private corporations are doing. Their managers are attempting to build up business and to get the highest prices possible from the business point of view, to make their road a paying one and a popular one. That would be their object, but the effort of the government in controlling the railways would be higher than that. It might be said that a railway was required through a particular portion of the country. It might not be a financial success at all. The portion of the system going through that country might be a losing road so far as the financial side of it was concerned. It might not pay its way for many years to come but it might be valuable in developing and opening up the country, and therefore the government with political foresight and having regard to the higher politics of the country would control such a road. Now, the hon. Minister of Railways and Canals says that the Australian colonies and New Zealand started out to build railways. Our condition and our circumstances are very widely different because the great railways, the great arteries through the country, are already built. We have them here to-day, we have 16,700 miles of railway in operation in the Dominion of Canada. We have people thickly settled, there is a network of railways, there is every railway accommodation and facility that can fairly be demanded by the people. All we have to do now Is not to plan how to build railways but to provide amongst other things against the great evil of unnecessarily duplicating lines of railway. There can be no more wasteful expenditure of public money than the building of parallel lines of railway. Last session there was up in the House the question of running a line of railway parallel to the Michigan Central Railway up in the counties of Essex and Kent and the government took power, then, if I remember correctly, to investigate the
matter and give the subsidy if, in their judgment, after full investigation, they should so decide and we heard the other day, I think, from the hon. Minister of Railways and Canals that the subsidy had been given to a line running side by side with another railway. Now, I object to that use of the money of the people of Canada. The Rainy River Railway case is practically another example. They say that the commercial necessities of the country require that we shall have two lines of railway out of Manitoba and the North-west Territories to carry the freight. If that lie the case let the second line be a commercial undertaking because the justification for tlie second line is that the business has so largely increased as to make its construction necessary. If that be the case, then that railway should be built, not by the enormous subsidies given by the Dominion and by the provinces of Ontario and Manitoba-which we are told would in themselves be nearly sufficient to construct the road-but it should be built as a strictly commercial undertaking. If we had government control of these roads the evils which are pointed out would not exist and the money of the Canadian people would not be diverted from useful enterprises to the wasteful extravagance of duplicating lines of railways. We all remember that a few years ago they had almost a revolution in Manitoba because the Dominion government had refused permission for this railway to enter that province. The pressure brought to bear upon the government of Canada was so great at that time, that the government was compelled to back down from the position they assumed and were forced to allow the Northern Pacific to enter1 Manitoba. The people of the province were promised that there would be competition and that competition would cheapen rates and prove of an inestimable value to the province. But what occurred ? Why, Sir, we have the fact admitted to-day that the scheme was an absolute failure and that no competition and no cheapening of rates resulted. This railway company took the money of the people of Manitoba and they turned around and made an arrangement with the Canadian Pacific Railway and the same rates were charged as before. In the province of Ontario there is no competition between the Canadian Pacific Railway and the Grand Trunk Railway which tends to cheapen! rates. Go to one of these railway companies and they will tell you that they cannot reduce passenger rates or freight rates because they have made, an arrangement with the other company, and the stipulated rates must be lived up to by both. They will tell you that they cannot run an excursion even to a competing point without consulting the other railway company and insisting upon the terms mutually agreed upon. These are great evils which exist to-day, and we are threatened with the further great evil that

our Canadian railways may at any moment be handed over to Individuals foreign and hostile to the interests of Canada ; to individuals who would make the Canadian lines subservient to the lines of the United States, a condition of things which would work ruin to; our people. Do we not see to-day that the Grand Trunk Railway has not its summer terminus at Montreal or Quebec, nor its winter terminus at Halifax or St. John ? Do they not announce that their summer and winter services will be at Portland ? I say, Sir, that we should use the powers that the parliament of Canada undoubtedly possesses to look after the interests of our Canadian people, to see that the ports of Quebec and Montreal, of Halifax and St. John, and this new port of Sydney shall get the Canadian business so that the harbours we have built up at vast cost shall not be deserted. We all know that to the point to which the freight is carried, there will the shipping go to take it across the ocean. It is absurd to say that although the Grand Trunk Railway carries its freight to Portland, and the Canadian Pacific Railway may carry its freight to Boston, there will still be a great trade for the port of Montreal. Sir, if our Canadian railways carry the produce of Canada and the United States freight in transit through Canada, to American shipping points, then there will be no trade for our Canadian ports. It is the duty of this parliament to look after the interests of the Canadian people. The railways will not do it. It is true we have had an incompetence in the government; we have had the Minister of Public Works (Hon. Mr. Tarte) splurging around doing great things for the port of Montreal in his mind, but actually accomplishing little or nothing for five years. We have had him making great pretensions of what he was going to do at Port Colborne to make it a transhipping point, but we would like to know what he has actually done. He cannot tell us, because he has accomplished but very little. However that may be, it is not the point. The point is that the Canadian people are capable of self government. We surely have the material to properly administer our affairs and to control our business. I have faith in the people of Canada that they will do so, and whether it is done by a commission, or whether it is done by a minister, or whether it is done by a combination of both a minister and a commission, it should be done by ourselves. The Minister of Railways (Hon. Mr. Blair) told us that in New South Wales they had a commission (independent, I presume, of the minister) but they were not satisfied with it, and so they adopted the new plan of having three commissioners, one the Minister of Railways and the other two railway men of experience, and although the minister did not attend to the details yet if a difference arose he had the veto power. The minister (Hon. Mr. Blair) points to that as Mr. WALLACE.
a conspicuous instance of the failure of a commission, but if it is the better way to give the minister for the time being a veto power, then let us adopt that system which has to commend it the experience of other colonies. Surely there are means which will remove the control of our railways from the political arena so far as the details are concerned, and still leave the supreme power over them to the parliament of Canada and to the government of Canada which represents parliament. Sir, public opinion is rapidly forming on this question, and as has been said by the member for Labelle (Mr. Bourassa) and the hon. member for South Brant (Mr. Heyd), thousands of people outside of parliament are eagerly watching the event transpiring today, and are coming rapidly to the conclusion that it is the duty of the government to promulgate a policy in this regard. The government of this country is bound to have a policy on all great questions of public interest, and to express it to the people of Canada. Sir, the people of Canada are eagerly watching for the announcement of the policy of the government in this respect. But, Sir, as far as we learn, the government have very little opinion upon it ; and the only one who spoke, the Minister of Railways, has thrown cold water on the proposition for any further government ownership or control of railways. In that, Sir, I venture to say that he and the government for whom he is speaking, do not represent the views of the people of Canada.

Mr. Speaker, as this question presents itself to my mind, there are three issues before us. One is the political control by the government of the Intercolonial Railway, a government railway; another is the non-political control of the Intercolonial Railway by a commission; and the other is the state ownership of all railways. Taking for granted that the motion of the hon. member for East York (Mr. Maclean)-not his speech-refers to the non-political control of the Intercolonial Railway, I shall have pleasure in supporting it. My hon. friend from Labelle (Mr. Bourassa) spoke for the motion and is going to vote against it. My hon. friend from East York made the motion and spoke against it. We hear a great deal of discussion about the danger that exists of foreign control of the Canadian Pacific Railway and the Grand Trunk Railway. To-day, Sir, the stock of both of these railways is controlled by foreigners. The trade of Portland, Boston, and a large portion of the trade of New York is being built up by these railways. For years the freight charges on these railways have been as they are to-day as low to Boston and Portland, as to Montreal, and in some cases lower. This has been going on for many a day, and I presume that it will

continue for a considerable period longer. The danger Is not coming on; it has been in existence for many a long year, and I am glad that the people are at last waking up to the need of building up Canadian seaport towns and cities, and putting a stop, so far as they can, to the building up of American cities by Canadian railways. The control of the Australian railways by commissions is reported to work very satisfactorily. The railways there are practically all government railways; but there is this peculiarity about them. They run to large cities, and do not intersect the country with branch lines to the same extent as is the case in Canada. In South Africa the railways are all owned by the government, but their control is non-political, and they are, I believe, working remarkably well. The only objection I have heard urged against the non-political control of government roads was that the commissioners do not keep pace with the times in regard to freight rates. That would be corrected, however, by the competition of other roads in this country. In New Zealand and the Australian colonies there is no competition; but in Canada there would be, and the commissioners would be kept up to the mark. I have pleasure in supporting the motion of the hon. member for Bast York on the understanding that it means the non-political control of the Intercolonial Railway, and not, as his speech indicated, the government ownership of railways.
Amendment negatived.

Motion agreed to, and House went into Committee.
Charges of management	 $17,443 80

It will be noticed that there are several small increases in the contingent accounts of the different offices throughout the country. The largest item of increase is $5,000 on account of the printing of Dominion notes. That arises from the general expansion of business throughout the country. There is an increase of $650 in the item of expenses in connection with the issue and redemption of Dominion notes. That is made up of small increases of $30, which are contemplated to the young ladies engaged in that branch.
speakername: The MINISTER OF FINANCE (Hon. W. S. Fielding).

speechtext: Will the hon. gentleman say why he has increased these salaries?

I did not mention any particular salaries, but I said there were several votes taken in contemplation of increases. I can give the hon. gentleman the items. The increase of $150 in Winnipeg is explained by the fact that a young lad who has been doing minor clerical work is put on the permanent list at the not very extravagant salary of $350 per annum.
At Charlottetown it is contemplated to take authority to give two increases of $100 each. I think these are the only salary increases which are provided for here.
I thought the hon. gentleman spoke of general increases to a number of young ladies ?
Yes, I say there are $30 increases to a number of young ladies engaged in the work of signing notes. These are persons who are poorly paid and they are given their $30 increase.
Would the hon. gentleman tell us now whether he is prepared to recognize the claims of the letter carriers of this country in the same way ?
When we come to the Post Office Department, that question will be settled.

The hon. gentleman has raised the principle of a poorly paid portion of the public service getting an increase, and we are thus within our rights in asking whether he will apply that principle to the poorly paid letter carriers. I would be quite willing to vote for this increase if the hon. gentleman will tell me that when he comes to the Post Office Department he will recognize the claims of the letter carriers.
If my hon. friend will show me any letter carrier who receives less money, I will be almost disposed to agree with him.

The letter carriers have families to support, and these ladies have no one probably to keep but themselves ; and if one section of the service is to be recognized, the hon. minister ought to be able to tell us whether he proposes to recognize another poorly paid section.

I will have to hand my hon. friend over to the tender mercies of the Postmaster General in respect of the letter carriers, and I do not think he will be found ungenerous. The increases I ask for are very small and are given to the fair sex, and I appeal to my hon. friend's gallantry to allow them to pass.
I am not objecting, but would like to see the men getting a fair proportion as well.
What are the salaries of these employees ?
After these increases are given, the highest salary paid will only be $530, and the salaries of these ladies range down to $430 or thereabouts.
That is a pretty good salary compared with that given the letter carriers.
Might X ask some information as to the details of the item for commissions on the payment of interest on public debt. What bank receives the commission?
The Bank of Montreal and the agent of the government in London.
What commission does it receive ?
The arrangement is an old one, made some years ago, and has not been altered. It is quite a small commission, but I could not give the exact fraction from memory.
The hon. gentleman will find the details on page G-12 of the Auditor General's Report.
I see there is an increase of $5,000 over the sum of $55,000 paid last year for printing Dominion notes. Has the increase of printing been so great as to justify this large increase ?
There is no increase in the rates, which are established by contract, but in the amount of business done on account of these growing times.
What is the amount of notes printed ?

The increase in the circulation is in proportion to the general increase in the volume of business. As the trade of the country expands, you have to provide more notes. Instead of providing too many, we are receiving criticism for not issuing new notes fast enough. The complaint is that many of the notes have been years in circulation, and are not as clean as they should be.
Are the plates on which these notes are printed still being engraved in the United States?

The system which has obtained for several years continues. All the work of engraving is done in Canada, but the dies on which the plates are made, are, under the terms of the agreement, permitted to be made in the United States.
I would like the hon. Minister of Finance to tell us what proportion of notes this increase of $5,000 represents. It is an increase of one-tenth.

The hon. minister does not seem to have seen his way clear to so amend the law as to make it unnecessary to have this provision so often in the estimates-1 notwithstanding anything in the Civil Service Act.' I have brought that to the attention of the hon. gentleman on more than one occasion, and have reasons that seem to me to make it undesirable that items should appear in that form, and have suggested that it would be better to amend the law. I presume the hon. gentleman has not seen his way clear to take that course.

The difficulty of course is that the law deals with matters generally, and these items are necessarily of an exceptional character. It might be difficult to frame a law which would cover all these cases. The theory is that the general outline of the Civil Service Act may be considered right, but in exceptional circumstances, when it is desired to give a larger increase than is authorized by the Act, these words have to be inserted. It may be said they occur often, but in proportion to the total number of officials in the service it will be found that they occur very seldom.
What is the reason for the inclusion of the words in this particular item ?

Because the gentleman named in the Governor General's office would receive a larger salary and a larger increase than he would be permitted to receive by the ordinary operation of the Civil Service Act. He would only be entitled to get, by the ordinary method of statutory increase, $50. The proposal is to give him $150. The gentleman's name is Walker.
Has he received the usual statutory increase during the past two or three years ?
Yes, this is a special increase.
Notwithstanding the fact that he received the usual increases during the past two or three years ?
Yes.
What particular service does he render to entitle him to a special increase of $150 while the other clerks are practically not getting any at all ?

In all the departments there will be found some officials who are deemed specially worthy of an increase, and the officials who are connected with the Governor General's department have reported this gentleman as especially worthy, and we have accepted the responsibility of recommending the increase.
How long has he been in the service ?
He has been there for quite a long time. He is an old official.

I would like to ask the Minister of Finance where he expects this thing to end, of refusing those in the civil service their promotion, or rather the statutory increase to which they seem to be entitled. I am not going to argue the question upon the ground that has been discussed here on many occasions, whether they were legally entitled to it or not. The government have contended from time to time that they were not, while others have taken the opposite ground. But, I want to point out that we are constantly met with difficulties from that system being carried out. There is gross favouritism appearing upon the surface; I will not say that it is so in reality, but, I say the hon. gentlemen expose themselves to fair criticism when they do that kind of thing. Instead of laying down one rule which should be carried out in every instance, we find this exceptional treatment from year to year growing worse. We have estimates filled with that saving clause ' notwithstanding anything in the Civil Service Act to the contrary.' I will venture to say in looking over the estimates that it will be found to occur oftener than last year, for the simple reason that hon. gentlemen have taken it into their own hands to set aside the law. The right hon. gentleman seems to be amused at it. It is not a matter of amusement. If he were in the position of these gentlemen who have to live at the beck and nod of their superiors, with their merits no longer an element entitling them to receive what the law allows, he would not be amused. I say it is not fair, it is dealing unfairly with the civil service and putting them in an unfair position. The end can only come when we have adopted a system that the civil service of this country should be entirely independent of any government. We are now entering upon a

discussion of the estimates, and we are met with these unsavoury items, I say unsavoury, because they lead to such evils that they will never be rectified until the government go back to the old system.

I think the hon. gentleman will find, as respects the general question of statutory increases, that we rather liberally interpret that declaration this year, and he will not have so much reason to complain as he supposes.

I remember his character in the department and his extreme modesty, and doubt very much if he has ventured to press his case on the attention of the government, and I hope that in bringing his name to the attention of the government, I am at least doing him no injury. It is not encouraging to men of exceptional ability, who graduate in our universities and enter the public service, that their ability should not receive fit acknowledgment. When I was in the Department of Marine and Fisheries, we had a very able and costly officer, so far as our exchequer was concerned, in Commander Boulton, who did very good work indeed, in organizing the Hydrographic service on the lakes. He was borrowed from the Admiralty and we had to give him his imperial pay and what was called a colonial allowance, fixed by the Imperial navy, or something like $5,000 a year, in all. He got the assistance of Mr. Stewart, who came on the staff without any political influence, but solely on his merits, and who was a graduate of the Kingston Royal Military College, especially recommended for his ability. After a year or two of service under Commander Boulton, Commander Boulton was asked what were his qualifications for the work. He came in at a small salary of some $600 or $700, and his salary had risen

to $1,000 or $1,100. Notwithstanding tlie fact that Commander Boulton well knew what would be the result, he gave a very strong certificate in favour of Mr. Stewart. Being not only an able man, but an English officer and gentleman, Captain Boulton gave Mr. Stewart the highest possible recommendation, and said he was quite satisfied that any charts made under Mr. Stewart's supervision, after survey made by him, would be acceptable by the- Admiralty as Admiralty charts. Mr. Stewart took Commander Boulton's place. It was my intention to advance Mr. Stewart as rapidly as possible, as such men are very rare in all the colonies. The Admiralty has had to lend men like Commander Boulton, at very high salaries, to other colonies, and I question whether in any of the colonies there is any superior to Mr. Stewart in charge of that high class of work, and I do not believe there is an officer performing similar duties in the Imperial service to-day, under the Admiralty or any colonial government, with such small pay.

What we would like the hon. gentleman to explain to us is the occasion for that increase in the cost of printing. Why is it that an increase in the printing is necessary ?

I will bring the information.
Item allowed to stand.
Post Office Department-
Clerical and other assistance, including $50 to pay W. Cooch, a packer and sorter for the technical work of inspecting letter carriers' boots, and $120 to pay S. J. Carter, of the dead letter office at Winnipeg, a provisional allowance for excessive cost of living in Manitoba, notwithstanding anything in the Civil Service Act.... $32,355
Printing and	stationery	  21,000
Sundries	 4,000
Balancing and summarizing depositors' accounts at close of year ending June 30,1901	 3,425
I think we had something relating to this same matter last year, in regard to this party, who, I believe, was removed from the city of Ottawa. Perhaps we will have some explanation of this item.

There are only two increases in this vote, one an increase of $50 to a man named Cooch. Cooch is a packer, and being on that service could not, without special reference in the vote, be allowed any increase other than the normal one, but he performs some special work, the work of examining the boots. Mr. Sidney Smith, the head of the stores branch, has recommended him, and thinks him very well entitled to be paid for that service. It is a valuable service, and we would either have to pay him or engage some person especially for it.
Are the boots propured by tender ?
Well, I really do not remember how they are obtained, now, They have been buying them in the same way for many a year.
No change ?

No, I have made no change in the system; we change the boots occasionally, that is all. The $150 is what I think the hon. member for Bothwell (Mr. Clancy) has particularly alluded to. His memory is excellent. We did have a reference to this gentleman foefore. Mr. Carter has been transferred from Ottawa to Winnipeg, although he is still in the inside service technically. The dead letter branch belongs to the inside service, but when we decentralized it and opened up two or three offices, this gentleman was sent up to look after the Winnipeg office. We propose to give him this special grant on account of the extra cost of living in Winnipeg.

It is not a new thing to have it stated to the House that gentlemen are employed on the ground of being able Mr. BORDEN (Halifax).
to do some technical work. This is going-pretty far. I am not objecting at all to the party in question, but it never ocurred to me that it required much technical skill to examine boots. What is the nature of the examination that is made and the extent of it ?
There are 1,816 pairs of letter carriers' boots examined per annum, and the estimated time occupied is three weeks.
Is it to see that the union label is on the boots ?
I suppose the real object is to see that the boots are of good quality.
Well heeled.
Will the hon. gentleman tell the committee what was the occupation of Mr. Cooch before ? Is he a practical boot maker ?
He was a shoemaker by trade.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: I would like to inquire if Mr. Cooch is the packer referred to in item No. 21 for the Post Office Department. I see one packer is paid $300 a year. If this $50 is additional to that $300 a year, I will gladly support it, for I do not think the hon. Minister of Labour, who happens to be the Postmaster General, would want a man to work for a year as a packer for less than $1 a day. I hope this $50 given for this technical work of inspecting the boots is to the packer who is put down for the small sum of $300 a year.

Mr. Chairman, I take exception to the wording of this paragraph, which reads :
To pay S. J. Carter of the dead letter office at Winnipeg a provisional allowance for excessive cost of living in Manitoba.
I do not think this is fair to that province. We wish immigrants to come into that province and we do not want to leave the impression that the cost of living there is excessive. In future editions of the estimates that term should be left out; indeed, it might be struck out now.
The point is well taken, and perhaps a better word can be substituted.
The words formerly used were ' provisional living allowance.'
I will find out the words which are used in the other votes and adhere to them.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Conservative Party (1867-1942)
speechtext: The Postmaster General did not tell me who this Mr. Cooch is.

Mr. Cooch was in receipt of $500, the maximum salary of his class, but last year parlia-

ment was good enough to Increase the maximum to $600, and Mr. Cooeh being an excellent officer, came in for an increase of $30.
How long has he been in the service ?
He was appointed on the 5th of August, 1872.
What portion of that $21,000 is for printing, and what portion for stationery.
This is a bulk sum, and it has not been customary to apportion it to each item, so that the officer cannot give me the information.
Is that printing done outside the government printing office?
It is all done in Ottawa.
Is it done at the Government Printing Bureau ?
It is all done by the King's Printer.
I see $300 mentioned here as the salary of a packer. That seems an absurd amount.
There is no man drawing that salary for this office which is vacant.
It is likely to remain vacant at that salary.
If there were an appointment to be made we could not pay more, but we found that salary on the statute-books when we took office.
If a vacancy can receive a salary of $300 that is a strong argument in favour of the letter carriers.
Would it not be well to draw the attention of the Minister of Labour (Hon. Mr. Mulock) to this, so that he can send his officer to make inquiries.

I will mention it to the Minister of Labour.
Department of Trade and Commerce-Contingencies	 $6,500
Is it the intention in this case as in others that the sum which appears here as a decrease shall appear as an increase in some other vote.
It is a transfer from one service to another, but that does not alter the number of officials.
Nor the amount to be paid each.

If they are employed as temporary writers, and are now made junior second-class clerks, they would of course get increased salaries.
Administration of justice	 $101,055
Is it necessary that this vote should stand in the absence of the Solicitor General ?

1 do not ask that the vote should stand, but when the Solicitor General is here I would like very much on some occasion, possibly when going into supply, to mention a matter in connection with this vote, and I give this as notice to the Solicitor General so that he may be prepared to discuss it. There seems to be a misunderstanding at the bar in Vancouver in regard to the arrangement for the sittings there of judges of the Supreme Court. Some time ago the question was raised as to whether there was a condition in the order in council, or in the commission, or in both, requiring the judge who was appointed at that time to reside in Vancouver. As a matter of fact no judge does reside in that city, although there is an impression that there was an arrangement made at the request of the bar of Vancouver to bring that about. One judge comes over generally on Monday and leaves on Friday or Saturday. That does not mean that there is always a judge from Tuesday to Friday, because for various reasons the judge who generally attends is not always able to keep these appointments. I wish the Solicitor General would refresh his memory on that matter, so that it may be known whether the government is in the position to have the wishes of the bar of Vancouver met, in order that we might have a resident judge in Vancouver.	.
I will see. that the matter is mentioned to the Solicitor General, and no doubt at a later stage he will deal with it.

This vote includes the item of $9,000 for the enforcement of the Alien Labour law. Is there any objection to letting the item stand ? We ought to have some explanations of it from the Solicitor General.
Might I ask for an explanation of the increase of $400 in the salaries of three judges in Prince Edward Island ?

I think the salaries of these judges are regulated by statute. When the Solicitor General is present, I am sure he will give my hon. friend the explanation.
Item allowed to stand.
Legislation-House of Commons contingencies, including $300 for clerical assistance for the leader of the opposition	 $25,000
I think the government would do well to take into consideration that item of $300. It is a very small amount for a first-class man.

I am quite agreeable, and perhaps when we bring down the supplementary estimates we may have something more.
Publishing debates	 $40,000
What does that include ?
It is for the publication of the Debates. We expect that this session will be a short one, and next session also, and that is the reason why we are simply asking for the sum of $40,000.

The question of more expedition being used in issuing ' Hansard ' after the House closes has been already before the Debates Committee. It seems to me that an unnecessary delay takes place now, and also that it might be possible to have * Hansard ' supplied to the members of the House at a much earlier hour on the day following the debate. I do not know whether the matter had best be discussed here or in the Debates Committee ; but I would like to ask the minister if any application was made by the Department of Printing for an additional press for the purpose of expediting the printing of ' Hansard.'

Yes- not particularly for the printing of * Hansard,' but for the several work of the department, there has been a suggestion that we should increase the plant. We did provide some increased plant a little while ago, but it is the kind of department that will always require a little more money.
I would like to ask if the vote of last year for this service, $60,000, was all expended ?
Yes, I understand that the vote of last year was fully expended, owing to the session being so long.

There is perhaps not so much complaint with regard to the publication of the bound volume as there is with regard to the issuing of the revised copy. I understand the press throughout the country does not receive ' Hansard ' until revised and printed, and there is usually a delay of ten or twelve days before that is done. It seems to me that that time should be shortened at least one-half. There is no reason why the revised * Hansard ' should not be issued say between five days after the unrevised edition is published. This would be a very great convenience to people in the country. We get extra copies of the revised edition to send out, and in the case of important speeches on special subjects, the subject is almost too cold by the time the public receive the debates. I hope those in charge will use every effort possible to have the revised edition published at a much earlier date.

The printing of debates is entirely under the control of the Debates Sir CHARLES HIBBERT TTJPPER.
Committee, and the subject is one which should be discussed before that committee. I understand that last year this question was brought up several times and that some new scheme was devised in order to secure greater expedition in the distribution of ' Hansard.' I do not know what has been the result, but the Speaker of this House has nothing to do with the printing of the debates, and the members of the Debates Committee are doing their best to render justice in that regard, and I have no doubt will do their best to give the House satisfaction.

I am much obliged to Mr. Speaker for his explanation. I have never had the honour of being a member of the Debates Committee and thought this the proper place to draw public attention to the matter. Perhaps the committee will think it proper to take this into their consideration again.
Estimate of Sergeant-at-Arms	 $39,540

There is a decrease of $85. A new assistant messenger has been appointed who received $200 less than the former messenger, and on the other hand we are providing for an increase to two messengers at $30 each, one doorkeeper $30, and night watchman at $25.
Are these all permanent officers.
Yes.

There is a reduction of $20,000 in the amount provided for the Debates, because it is expected that this session will not be long, but why is there not a reduction provided in the case of extra sessional clerks, &c.?
We have voted the same amount for many years and have never provided for long sessions, but take a supplementary vote when necessary.
Some hon. gentlemen are desirous of going home, as tomorrow is a holiday. We have made very substantial progress, and I think we might now adjourn.

I agree with my hon. friend Mr. Borden (Halifax), that we have made a very fair degree of progress.
Some resolutions reported.
The PRIME MINISTER (Rt. Hon. Sir Wilfrid Laurier) moved the adjournment of the House.

Before the House adjourns I would like to mention the desirability of having the Committee on Public

Accounts organized. I understood that this committee was to have been called to-day. But that was not done, for some reason that 1 do not understand. Notices have been sent out to members of other committees announcing meetings for Thursday; but I, as a member of the Public Accounts Committee, have not received notice of the summoning of that committee for that day. 1 think it very desirable for the purpose of expediting the business of the session that this committee should be organized as early as possible. It is very natural to suppose that that committee will have business to transact, and business in which a great many members of the House are more or less interested. 1 would suggest to the right hon. Prime Minister that he or whoever is charged with that duty should see to it that this committee is summoned for Thursday.

My instructions were that all committees should be summoned for Thursday. If that has not been done in the case of the Public Accounts Committee it must have been a mistake. X will see to it that the committee is summoned for the following day.
Motion agreed to, and House adjourned at 9.45 p.m.
